q: What are the symptoms of jaundice?
a: Symptoms of jaundice include yellowing of the skin and the white part of the eyes. It can also cause itchiness, darker urine, and lighter stools.

q: What can cause jaundice?
a: Jaundice can occur due to the buildup of bilirubin in the body. Some possible causes include alcohol-related liver disease, gallstones, hepatitis, pancreatitis, and sickle cell disease.

q: How can I get urgent medical help for jaundice?
a: If you notice yellowing of your skin or the whites of your eyes, it is important to seek urgent medical help. You can ask for an urgent GP appointment or contact NHS 111 for assistance.

q: What is newborn jaundice?
a: Newborn jaundice is a common condition in newborn babies and is usually harmless. It causes yellowing of the skin and eyes and typically resolves on its own.

q: Are there any specific symptoms of jaundice in newborns?
a: Yes, newborn jaundice may cause yellowing of the skin and eyes in babies. However, it is important to consult a doctor for a proper diagnosis and treatment.

q: How can I differentiate between normal skin color and jaundice?
a: In individuals with brown or black skin, yellowing of the skin due to jaundice may be less noticeable. However, the white part of the eyes will still appear yellow.

q: What are the potential risks associated with jaundice?
a: Jaundice can be a sign of underlying liver disease or other serious conditions. It is important to seek medical attention to properly diagnose the cause and receive appropriate treatment.

q: Is jaundice a serious condition?
a: Jaundice itself can be a symptom of a serious underlying condition, such as liver disease. It is important to consult a healthcare professional for a proper diagnosis and treatment.

q: What treatments are available for jaundice?
a: The treatment for jaundice depends on the underlying cause. It may involve addressing liver disease, gallstones, hepatitis, pancreatitis, or other related conditions.

q: How can I prevent jaundice?
a: Preventing jaundice involves maintaining a healthy lifestyle, avoiding excessive alcohol consumption, practicing safe sex to prevent hepatitis, and seeking medical advice for any underlying health conditions.
